Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I sat in the quiet corner of the library, my mentor’s email open on my laptop. She’d suggested a few articles to read, nothing urgent, but she always said, “The best mentees go the extra mile.” I wanted to impress her, to show I was committed, so I’d planned to spend the afternoon reading. But my phone buzzed—a reminder that today was the last day to vote. I rushed to the polling station, only to be told by an official that my registration had a mismatch. If I wanted my vote to count, I had to fill out a provisional ballot form, and the station closed in ten minutes. The official’s instructions were clear: no mistakes, no delays. My mind raced. If I stayed, I’d have no time for the reading my mentor expected. If I left, I’d miss my chance to vote. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
